Sadly, none of this science applies directly if you have one of a number of sleep disorders that affect your otherwise semi-predictable sleep cycle and circadian rhythm.

I have narcolepsy which, is less about falling asleep randomly than it is about your brain not reliably sending signals controlling sleepiness, wakefulness, stages of sleep, sleep paralysis, and even muscle tone. Sadly, narcoleptics may never have predictable sleep rhythms, and fragmented sleep is really all that's possible.

I had a really bad experience with interrupting deep sleep and 4 months later I'm still suffering the effects! When I had my baby things didn't go exactly according to plan and  I ended up not being to go home straight away... after the doctors broke my waters, gave me hormones, etc etc, over 24 hours later my baby was finally born! I don't what it was but I just couldn't sleep but finally towards the end of the day I started getting tired and sleepy. Now... my partner wasn't allowed to stay at the hospital with me, so after he went home I finally closed my eyes... only to be woken up by my baby! I did what I had to do and put him down to sleep again.. but he kept waking up! After trying so many times (4 hours laters) I decided to bring him to my bed but again... I couldn't sleep! I was afraid because I was so tired I'd fall asleep deeply and hurt him without noticing. I kept forcing myself to stay awake and if I fell asleep it was never for long.. it was like my head had its own alarm clock.. Well, hours and hours passed, the staff started to give breakfast and my partner arrived "where did time go?" still.. I couldn't sleep!! Every time I was sleeping really well, I was interrupted by some doctor wanting a blood sample, or a nurse giving me medication or doing obs :( After a while I started to feel really energetic but very light headed and felt some numbness... even my tongue was numb.. I don't know how things went, all I know is that all of a sudden the numbness got worse, I could walk fine but at the same time I couldn't feel my legs properly, I started having twitches with my eyes, mouth, tongue, then arms, legs and eventually having full body spasms (they even thought I was epileptic).. I still felt like I didn't want to sleep though.. apparently because I was so tired after labour but my sleep was interrupted all the time, my brain decided to go all weird and act as if I needed to sleep but didn't send the message to tell me I was sleepy. I needed pills to teach my brain how to sleep again but now, 4 months later I still get twitches (mainly just with my eyes and mouth) if I start getting really tired and had a few more episodes of full body spasms when I was really stressed!

The trick: Most sleep cycles are 45 min. Set your alarm to go off at the end of a 45 minute cycle, during REM (the lightest sleep stage). e.g. if you go to bed at 12am, set the alarm for 6am, 6:45am or 7:30am. You won't feel as groggy when alarm goes off!  My "snooze button" is 45 minutes: 1st alarm at 6:45 as my warning (turn it off when it buzzes), then 2nd alarm at 7:30 to get up. It's perfect! Try it!

Question: How biologically affects to your body, in short and long term, having your sleep schedule switched? I mean particularly, sleep during the day and awake during night. Seems to goes against our evolutionary nature (circadian rhythm). I work at an astronomical observatory, so during a 7 days shift I have this switched schedule and the next 7 days off work I go back to the normal sleep during night. Consider that, in my case, work and living place is -30deg latitude, so night working hours are different between winter and summer.
A lot of related questions come to my mind like... Can we really adapt? is it different for every person? are some people more productive during night than others? among others questions. I think there a lot to explore about this subject and to create one of your amazing videos!

It takes at least 30 minutes to get back into, what is known as, deep sleep. Most people don't snooze for so long, but only for ~15 minutes. This ~15 minutes of sleep, right after you woke up from a longer sleep is almost the same as, what is knows as, a "Powernap", which is actually really healthy for you. So it's all about how long you snooze (10-20 is good, 30+ is bad.)
Cortisol also regulates insulin & blood sugar. You can literally get diabetes from screwing with your sleep/wake cycle. It's a big deal.

AsapSCIENCE needs to get their facts straight ASAP. There are indeed stages of sleep, but you cannot progress to a 'deeper stage' of sleep than you woke from in the 10mins it takes to snooze. Also the studies that mention 'fragmented sleep' refer to people who do not take their sleep in lump sums (one long period of rest at night), but try to scatter it throughout the day and replace or greatly reduce their nightly sleep. Essentially, these topics are almost irrelevant to the topic at hand.

They should have instead focused on the state of sleep you WOULD go into during 'snooze' which would be the LIGHTEST levels of sleep, which are not the restorative, deeper levels of sleep that your body needs to feel rejuvenated.

You can also use things like the UP band to wake you. It sits on your wrist and monitors your movement to determine what stage of sleep you're in and will wake you when you're in your lightest stage, and you will therefore experience the least amount of sleep inertia.

Another great way is to use nature's alarm clock... light! As light filters in through your windows, your brain detects light level change and will start producing chemicals to wake you up. Without these environmental cues, you'll probably wake up in a deep sleep stage.

The rest of the video was alright... but let's not teach pseudoscience.

I set an alarm to wake me up 45 minutes ahead of my intended wake-up time.  That way I can (sort of) control what stage of my sleep cycle my alarm will be interrupting.  Almost every time, it puts me at a favorable point in my sleep cycle when the real wake up time comes.  The problem is, sometimes anticipating to turn off my alarm leads to me doing it almost reflexively and I don't wake up, negating the point of the alarm in the first place.

good question. sleep walkers do not act out their dreams. sleep walking happens in stage 2 sleep whereas dreams happen in REM sleep. During REM sleep, the body is paralyzed unless you have a REM disorder. The causes of this are not well understood because sleep itself is still somewhat of a mystery. So when people scream in their sleep, it is not from a nightmare or anything. And sometimes people wake up paralyzed because their body is still stuck in REM mode but the brain is awake. CRAZY!

its about the 4 sleep stages+REM. That's the 90 min sleep cycles we go through everytime we sleep. 1st stage is light sleep lasting no more than about 1 minute. 2nd stage is like 30 mins. you get bursts of rapid brain activity. 3rd stage is the start of really deep sleep. it's hard to wake someone up. 4th is also deep sleep. REM is what's giving you the boner. it stands for Rapid Eye movement. This is where dreaming happens. if you watch a person in REM you will see their eyelids moving.

not naps, but power naps. there are 2 stages of sleep, "light sleep" and REM or "deep sleep." power naps help to make up for lost sleep and typically dont last very long. like this video stated, when interrupted during deep sleep it will lead you to feeling even more tired than when in light sleep. power naps dont and shouldnt last long enough for you to fall into deep sleep, but you still get that moments rest, thus making you feel more alert and awake.

Seen another video on it, but short napping is good. There's more to the sleep cycle than simply "deep asleep" and "pre-wake up stage".
It takes about 20 minutes from when you go to sleep for the first time before you enter REM or deep sleep, which is where you get the problem of sleep inertia when you wake up. 
Short power naps can provide you with a boost of energy without the negative effects of sleep inertia.

A mirror reflects all the colors so well that it doesn't absorb any.  All the light bounces off perfectly straight, and thus we see the object the light was coming from, or the reflection.  Again, google can give a better explanation.

White light is all the colors of the color specturm, and black is the absence of light, no color.  Black pigment (Paints) is all the colors combined, and as a result reflects no color, but absorbs it all letting off heat - that's why black cars heat up quicker.  White reflects all the colors, thus it doesn't heat up as much, and as mentioned, all colors combined is white.  Solids get their color by what what colors they reflect/absorb.

I have a question about this.
What if you never get to get out of bed because your using the snooze button too much?

One way to think about it (Along the lines of "radical acceptance") Imagine that your grade is predetermined. What you do between the beginning and end makes no difference. Just put the first thing that comes to mind. Letting your "sub-conscious" take over, or the first thing that comes to mind, and not focusing too much, you'll not only be more relaxed but generally do better. 

Another irony. The more you study, the more confident you'll be, the less you worry, the better you do.

When your mind is under pressure, it suppresses the synapses, neural pathways that go to the information you need.  That's why people are more creative when they're relaxed and can let their minds wander. Learn some relaxation techniques.  Or just stress about trying to relax ;-)

It also helps to set a "mental alarm clock." Its rather amazing even if you don't have a perfectly consistent rhythm. Look at the clock, how many hours you have, imagine how much that sleep feels like, even where the sun will be coming in the window, then make a mental note of the time to wake up. You'd be surprised. Some people can wake up 5 mins before their alarm even with an erratic sleep schedule. I've successfully done it a couple times. Train your body and mind, you'd be surprised.

I'm not ASAP science, but I can help you out! In our autonomic nervous system, there are special neurons that let us understand someone else's emotions called mirror neurons. These also let you learn through imitation. When someone yawns, your mirror neurons interpret that as something you should empathise with and you yawn in response in an attempt to "empathise" with that person. Hope it helps!

Yawning when others yawn, the study suggests, is a sign of empathy and a form of social bonding. Kids don't develop this deeply rooted behavior until around age four, the study found. Kids with autism are half as likely to catch yawns. In the most severe cases, they never do.
For reasons scientists still can't explain, spontaneous yawning continues throughout life. (Studies have shot down theories about yawning to bring in more oxygen.) In fact, all vertebrates yawn, including snakes and lizards

I am not with Asap Science, but am qualified to answer this question.
Yawns are contagious and the reason lies in the evolutionary development (I hope you are not in one of those states, where evolution never happened) of humans as a social being. Now, I will not go in the deeper brain functioning but will tell you about certain hormones. Dopamine and Oxytocin are two most important Happy Hormones. We feel happy when they are released in our brains.

Now think that in pre-modern-human days, when a herd of animals is sitting in a forest and a few members are on a lookout for predators. if any single member is inattentive it leads to a lower security for the whole herd. So when a single member grows tired and YAWNS, the brain releases the Happy hormones. Other members see this and their brain also starts to crave the refreshing cocktail of hormones so they also yawn and so a little bit later the whole group has yawned.

The whole group is fresh now and is on lookout duty with a reset on its tiredness. This became a very important factor in the longer survival and eventually it became so much absorbed in to our biochemistry. Now this is not just among us humans, the contagiousness of yawns has been seen in other animals as well specially mammals.

Here is another thing, its contagiousness is not bound by the species, sometimes your dog yawns and so do you or the other way. That is for the contagious character of a yawn. Other than releasing hormones, a yawn also increases the blood oxygen levels and thus provides our brain with a fresh supply of oxygen. I hope this helps, you can also read many other papers related to the yawns.

I am not exactly an expert but cellphones like many other devices such as radios use electromagnetic radiation to communicate. Electromagnetic radiation is a type energy emitted and absorbed by objects, and the radiation is emitted in photons, which are small particles. Visible light is one type of electromagnetic radiation and other types include infrared, and ultraviolet. All this electromagnetic radiation travels at the speed of light which is why phone calls can travel so quickly.

Yes, reading with the voice in your head is called sub-vocalization. It takes longer to read like this because your brain has to process how you would move your lips, even though you aren't actually moving them. This is pretty much the first habit you need to kick to start speed reading. Chances are you already do it with some things, for instance when you look at a stop sign you probably know it says "stop" without saying it in your mind. If you want to know more read up on speed reading.
